G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified upon a showing that such modification is in the best interests of the children and based on a material change in circumstances.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification of an existing order concerning the custody and parenting plan for the minor children. Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the children currently reside in Massachusetts, and this court entered the original custody order that Plaintiff seeks to modify.

G.L. c. 265, \u00a7 13A.proposition: Defendant has since moved in with an individual (hereafter referred to as “the cohabitant”) who has a criminal history, including a conviction for assault and battery under G.L. c. 265, § 13A, and a prior restraining order issued pursuant to G.L. c. 209A due to allegations of domestic violence.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Defendant has since moved in with an individual (hereafter referred to as “the cohabitant”) who has a criminal history, including a conviction for assault and battery under G.L. c. 265, § 13A, and a prior restraining order issued pursuant to G.L. c. 209A due to allegations of domestic violence.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Custody determinations focus on the children’s safety and developmental needs.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames both custody and removal questions in terms of the children’s best interests, expressly including their emotional, physical, and developmental needs. In its articulation of the removal/best-interests standard, the opinion states that the effect of the move on the child and the child’s developmental needs must be evaluated, confirming that custody-related determinations focus on the child’s safety, well-being, and developmental interests rather than parental preferences alone.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Custody determinations focus on the children’s safety and developmental needs.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the best-interests-of-the-child standard and explains that custody determinations require weighing all factors relevant to the child’s needs and circumstances, including living conditions, stability, sibling relationships, and the impact on the child’s physical, mental, moral, and emotional health. This framing shows that custody decisions are centered on the child’s safety, wellbeing, and developmental needs, and the court then applies those factors to the facts of the case.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’....’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question. See Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000)… The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: The court may impose appropriate limitations on parenting time when there is evidence, as here, that the current arrangement is harmful to children.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on child support, attachment of assets, and modification of legal custody, not on imposing limitations on parenting time or visitation due to harm to the children. The only custody-related discussion concerns the inadequacy of findings to support a change from shared to sole legal custody; there is no analysis or holding about limiting parenting time because the arrangement is harmful. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, the judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings based on evidence within the record’ that awarding sole legal custody of the minor child to the defendant was in the best interests of the child.”

Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.raw_text: Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1994)
Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.proposition: The court may impose appropriate limitations on parenting time when there is evidence, as here, that the current arrangement is harmful to children.
Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, but only to affirm an award of sole legal and physical custody to the mother based on best interests and the father’s lack of appropriate plans. It does not address, analyze, or authorize imposing *limitations on parenting time* based on evidence that an existing parenting-time arrangement is harmful to the children. There is no discussion of visitation schedules, parenting-time restrictions, or modification of parenting time due to harm, so the case does not support the specific proposition cited.
Zatsky v. Zatsky, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 7 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Assessing the conduct of the parties and deciding what custody arrangments are in the best interests of the children rests in the sound discretion of the probate judge. Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1976). Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987). There was basis in the evidence to support the judge’s findings that the wife had been a nurturing mother, able to subordinate her emotional needs to those of the children, and that the father had made no plans for child care or suitable living quarters. The custody order was sound.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The behavior and criminal history of the cohabitant align with factors courts recognize as adverse to a child’s best interests, particularly where the safety and stability of the children are called into question.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses how violent, unsafe conduct within the home bears on the child’s best interests in custody determinations. The SJC endorses the view that domestic violence and abuse of family members must be explicitly considered because they present “special risks” and cause “distinctly grievous” harm to children, thereby making such behavior an adverse factor when assessing safety, stability, and best interests. While the case involves a violent parent rather than a nonparent cohabitant, the reasoning extends to any abusive household member whose conduct endangers the child’s security.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm… The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother.… Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child… will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The behavior and criminal history of the cohabitant align with factors courts recognize as adverse to a child’s best interests, particularly where the safety and stability of the children are called into question.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt does not discuss a cohabitant’s behavior or criminal history, nor does it apply or identify factors relating to a cohabitant as adverse to a child’s best interests. Instead, the concurrence concerns statutory interpretation of the paternity statute, relocation by a sole legal parent, and the impropriety of the judge’s relocation order. There is no analysis tying a cohabitant’s conduct to best‑interests factors, so this case does not support the proposition stated.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "Here, the critical and determining fact before the judge, and before us, in applying the provisions of the paternity statute is that the mother, an unquestionably fit parent, moved to New York with the child at a time when, as the child’s only legal parent, she was free to do so without the court’s or the putative father’s permission, even if the move disrupted arrangements she had previously made for visitation between the child and the putative father."

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The requested modifications are narrowly tailored to achieve the best interests of the children, consistent with Massachusetts law and case law, including Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), which emphasizes the Court’s obligation to safeguard children’s welfare in parenting arrangements.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case explicitly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 to require that removal decisions be made based on the children’s best interests, and repeatedly emphasizes the court’s duty to evaluate all circumstances affecting the children’s welfare in parenting/relocation arrangements. While Mason v. Coleman is a relocation case rather than a modification-order case, its articulation of the best-interests standard and the court’s obligation to safeguard children’s welfare in custody and parenting-time arrangements is consistent with the proposition for which it is cited.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’ … It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts… whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 38.proposition: Plaintiff has been forced to represent herself in seeking this modification and respectfully requests that the Court consider awarding her attorneys’ fees and costs should representation become necessary.

C.O. v. M.M., 442 Mass. 648 (2004).proposition: Plaintiff has been forced to represent herself in seeking this modification and respectfully requests that the Court consider awarding her attorneys’ fees and costs should representation become necessary.
C.O. v. M.M., 442 Mass. 648 (2004).support_reasoning: The opinion in C.O. v. M.M. concerns the standards for issuing a G.L. c. 209A abuse prevention order and the defendant’s due process rights at that hearing. It does not discuss attorney representation in civil modification proceedings, nor attorney’s fees or costs for a self‑represented party. Therefore, it offers no authority for the proposition that a plaintiff forced to represent herself may request or be awarded future attorney’s fees and costs.
